title: Car sponsor dumps Dan Carter over drink-driving charge
text:
Car sponsor dumps Dan Carter over drink-driving charge Last updated 11:18, February 21 2017 
As a brand ambassador for Land Rover, Dan Carter would visit club and school rugby teams. 
Dan Carter has lost a lucrative sponsorship with a car company because of his drink-driving charge. 
Carter was caught driving in Paris with excessive blood-alcohol levels last week and faces a court appearance. 
The fallout now includes glamour car manufacturer Land Rover dumping the All Blacks great who is playing in France's Top 14 championship. REUTERS 
Dan Carter faces testing times as the reality of his drink-driving charge hits home. 
Carter confirmed the development on his Facebook page on Tuesday, saying: "Over the last few days my management and I have had to front up to my sponsors. Not surprisingly, Land Rover, who for good reason have zero tolerance towards drink driving, have ended their relationship with me. I understand this completely and am disappointed I put them in this position." 
READ MORE: * Dan Carter returns to NZ 
Carter, who is battling a leg injury that has made him unavailable for French club Paris Racing, has returned to New Zealand. 
To his credit, Carter hasn't dodged the controversy. 
He used his Facebook page last week to confirm his driving indiscretion and also apologise for his actions, admitting he'd made "a massive error of judgment". Ad Feedback 
British manufacturer Land Rover has a high profile in rugby, being a major sponsor at the last two World Cups, in New Zealand and England. Carter, 34, was part of the All Blacks teams that won both of those tournaments. 
His efforts in helping New Zealand to their third title in 2015 earned him World Rugby's player of the year award. A post shared by Dan Carter (@dancarter_) on Sep 30, 2016 at 11:49am PDT 
He retired from international rugby after the 2015 tournament as the game's highest points scorer in tests, and shifted his focus to Paris with a mega deal at Racing 92. 
He had a squeaky clean image until last week's fateful night in the 17th district in Paris, near the Champs-Elysees, when he was stopped by police, allegedly speeding not carrying a driver's licence and recording an alcohol level of .98g/l, well above the legal limit of .5g/l. - Stuff
